content.body: Domenic: hi, I want to try to find a good direction for the link header/element refactor
content.formatted_body: Domenic: hi, I want to try to find a good direction for the link header/element refactor

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: hi, I want to try to find a good direction for the link header/element refactor
Domenic: hi, I want to try to find a good direction for the link header/element refactor

content.body: The way I was going was that all links are converted to the same "options" struct, either from a header or from an element, and then there is no need for each rel to do special header processing
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The way I was going was that all links are converted to the same "options" struct, either from a header or from an element, and then there is no need for each rel to do special header processing

content.body: ... but I can also go with having different "process header" and "process element" algorithms that end up funneling to functions like "preload" or "preconnect"
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: ... but I can also go with having different "process header" and "process element" algorithms that end up funneling to functions like "preload" or "preconnect"

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: so my main concern is the clarity of reading a given element's section. I am hoping: (a) it can be clear at a glance whether it supports elements/headers/early hints; (b) we move away from a defaults-and-overrides structure; (c) there is minimal duplication/maximal shared infrastructure.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: so my main concern is the clarity of reading a given element's section. I am hoping: (a) it can be clear at a glance whether it supports elements/headers/early hints; (b) we move away from a defaults-and-overrides structure; (c) there is minimal duplication/maximal shared infrastructure.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Noam Rosenthal: so my main concern is the clarity of reading a given element's section. I am hoping: (a) it can be clear at a glance whether it supports elements/headers/early hints; (b) we move away from a defaults-and-overrides structure; (c) there is minimal duplication/maximal shared infrastructure.

Noam Rosenthal: so my main concern is the clarity of reading a given element's section. I am hoping: (a) it can be clear at a glance whether it supports elements/headers/early hints; (b) we move away from a defaults-and-overrides structure; (c) there is minimal duplication/maximal shared infrastructure.

content.body: Domenic: ok, for (c) - I think it would be good if the common "Process link headers" extracted something like the options struct from the headers, before sending it to the different `rel` sections
content.formatted_body: Domenic: ok, for (c) - I think it would be good if the common "Process link headers" extracted something like the options struct from the headers, before sending it to the different rel sections

content.body: Options structs are good
Just commented on the thread too

content.body: (b) is mostly about fixing a preexisting problem but I think if we're doing (a) and (c) at the same time it's worth tackling (b)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (b) is mostly about fixing a preexisting problem but I think if we're doing (a) and (c) at the same time it's worth tackling (b)

content.body: ok, but without (b) and with options struct, how would you spell out the "process early hints" -> "handle headers for this type of link" transition?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: ok, but without (b) and with options struct, how would you spell out the "process early hints" -> "handle headers for this type of link" transition?

content.body: I guess by having "to handle headers for this type of link, do nothing" for each unsupported `rel` type?
content.formatted_body: I guess by having "to handle headers for this type of link, do nothing" for each unsupported rel type?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I guess by having "to handle headers for this type of link, do nothing" for each unsupported `rel` type?

content.body: Yes exactly
I think that's nice and super-obvious
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think that's nice and super-obvious

content.body: But we could also do something like "supported processing types"
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: But we could also do something like "supported processing types"

content.body: sure I can go with that. Sometimes my natural tendency is more minimalistic (defaults) but it's not always the most obvious for readers
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: sure I can go with that. Sometimes my natural tendency is more minimalistic (defaults) but it's not always the most obvious for readers

content.body: I think the "do nothing" duplication would be better than a list of supported types. It allows us to add new types without maintaining it in separate places
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think the "do nothing" duplication would be better than a list of supported types. It allows us to add new types without maintaining it in separate places
